cigarette: A rolled or stuffed paper-wrapped cylinder containing tobacco which is ignited for smoking. Highly addictive and hazardous to your health, increasing the risk of cancer, tuberculosis, asthma, heart disease, and many more.
yellow flower: Any type of [[flower]], whether real or fictional, that is colored [[yellow]].
pink background: Backgrounds with a solid or predominantly [[pink]] color. Can also apply to [[gradient background]] in conjunction with another background color.
sky:
Use this tag if the sky is used as a focal point, as a subject, or used as a background.

h1. See also

* [[blue sky]]
* [[cloudy sky]]
* [[clear sky]]
* [[night sky]]
* [[starry sky]]
* [[skyline]]

* [[sunrise]]
* [[sunset]]
* [[twilight]]
* [[dusk]]
bed:
A piece of furniture used for [[sleeping]].

Use this tag only if the bed is [b]clearly[/b] there rather than implied. If [[pillow]], bed edges, headboard, frames of any sort are not visible, use [[bed sheet]] without [[bed]].

The traditional, Japanese equivalent is the [[futon]].
open clothes: A variety of garments can be unbuttoned or otherwise left open, such as shirts, blouses, gowns, and robes.
hair between eyes: A hair bunch from the bangs that falls over the middle of the forehead, long enough to reach at least between the eyes of the person.
unworn hat:
A [[hat]] that currently isn't being worn.

For a character who normally wears a hat but their hat is totally absent, use [[no headwear]] instead.
holding weapon:
[[Holding]] any type of [[weapon]].

There are a handful of tags for the most common types of weapons:

* [[holding axe]]
* [[holding bow (weapon)]]
* [[holding crossbow]]
* [[holding grenade]]
* [[holding gun]]
* [[holding knife]]
* [[holding polearm]]
* [[holding rocket launcher]]
* [[holding sword]]

Other weapons can be found with a combination tag search:

* {{holding_weapon battle_axe}}
* {{holding_weapon mace}}
* {{holding_weapon club_(weapon)}}
* {{holding_sword katana}}
* {{holding_gun rifle}}
huge ass:
When a simple [[ass]] tag is not enough. Used only for asses that are proportionally bigger than the rest of the body. Not to be confused with [[wide_hips|wide hips]] or [[thick_thighs|thick thighs]] (though they may also be present) — the buttocks themselves should be proportionally exaggerated in these cases, protruding significantly backward behind the person. 

Note: An ass that only [i]looks[/i] larger because the subject is [[bent over]] or any ass that is slightly bigger in size than a [[flat ass]] or a normal-sized [[ass]] doesn't make it "huge". Above all, [b]size matters.[/b]
orgasm:
Sexual climax, a physiological and neurological response to sexual stimulation. It results in feelings of intense physical pleasure, release, and usually calm. During orgasm, men usually [[ejaculation|ejaculate]] [[cum|semen]] from the tip of their [[penis]]. Women usually produce an amount of liquid from their vaginal opening, and may also on occasion [[female_ejaculation|ejaculate]].

Tag applicable when it is apparent within an image that a character, usually a female, is experiencing an orgasm. This is usually shown most through the facial expression.
blurry: When part of the image is unsharp as a stylistic effect, or the emulation of "realistic" effects, such as looking through certain materials, in-image [[photo (medium)|photographs]] that are blurry, etc.
pointy ears: Any ear ending in a point. Usually [[elf]] or [[Vulcan]]-like, but can also refer to animal-like ears.
sex machine: A mechanical device used to simulate human [[sex|sexual intercourse]]. It is a more sophisticated version of the [[vibrator]]. These devices may be associated with, but are not limited to, [[BDSM]] play. Often involves [[stationary restraints]].
nose blush: When one blushes across the bridge of their nose.
glowing: An object or character that is radiating with light.
3girls:
An image depicting three female characters.

Dolls only count if they act on their own. Depictions of characters on paintings etc don't count unless it plays a major role in the work. If the presence of a character is only implicated it doesn't count.
buttons:
Buttons on clothing. Typically used to fasten together shirts, pants, or sleeves, but sometimes they are purely decorative.

For the type of button that is pressed like a switch, see [[push-button]].

For the type of button that is pinned on a shirt with a needle, see [[button badge]].
hand up:
When a single hand is raised to the upper torso or higher. When both hands are raised, use [[hands up]].

Use [[arm up]] when the hand is above eye level.
reaching:
Character physically reaching out for something, either with their hand(s)/leg(s) or other objects.

If the character is reaching toward the viewer, then it's [[reaching towards viewer]].

Usually accompanied by these tags:

* [[outstretched arm]]
* [[outstretched arms]]
* [[outstretched hand]]
* [[outstretched leg]]
glands of montgomery: Glands of Montgomery (or Montgomery's glands) are the small bumps sometimes visible in the areola.  The glands make oily secretions (lipoid fluid) to keep the areola and the nipple lubricated and protected.
gun:
A [[weapon]] that fires [[bullet]]s by way of explosive propellant.

This includes real world guns, but excludes [[science fiction]] [[energy gun]]s and other weapons that don't fire bullets.
hand on own arm:
When a character has one of their hands placed on their own arm.

If both hands are involved, use [[hands on own arms]].
prostration:
Bowing face down on [[all fours]], usually in submission or deep apology.

Also known as [b]orz[/b] or [b]OTL[/b], an emoticon that's supposed to look like a person on their knees, bent over.
drooling:
When [[saliva]] leaks from the mouth. 

Sometimes drawn as an indent in the lower lipline, in which case saliva is not actually present. Such cases should be tagged as [[mouth drool]], not as [[saliva]].
wire:
A thin strand or thread composed of metal.  This tag is only for images of bare metal wires and non-electrical types of wire, particularly those used as a weapon. 

Images that depict coated wires, especially those connected to a machine or piece of electronics, should only use the [[cable]] tag instead.  The only exception to this is if the coated wire is also exposing the metal underneath the coat, in which case it can be tagged [[wire]] in conjunction with the [[cable]] tag.

Images of no
torn clothes: Clothes that are in a [[torn]] state.
alternate muscle size: When a character has bigger or smaller muscles than they have in canon.
bangs:
Hair that drapes forward to hang in front of the forehead. Known in British English as a [b]fringe[/b].

As it would apply to almost every post on the site, the base [code]bangs[/code] tag is no longer used.
animal:
Use this tag for real animals that exist or have existed on earth. 

Please use [[monster]] or [[creature]] for fictional or mythical animals, such as [[griffin]]s, [[cabbit]]s, or [[jackalope]]s.

If the animal to be tagged is sizably larger than the other subjects, use [[oversized animal]]. Be sure to identify the correct [[size difference]], since it might be the [[miniboy|other]] way [[minigirl|around]].
horse girl:
A human girl with horse features, such as [[horse ears]] or a [[horse tail]].

Might also be applied to [[pegasus]] girls and [[unicorn girl]]s. Does not apply to characters with horse legs, such as [[centaur]]s or non-[[personification|personified]] [[My Little Pony]] characters.
murasa minamitsu:
The "Ghost of the Shipwreck". 

Stage 4 boss of [[Touhou]]'s [[Undefined Fantastic Object]] and playable character in [[Sunken Fossil World]]. 

Captain Murasa is the [[ghost]] of a drowned girl who earned notoriety for her ability to capsize ships, until she was adopted by [[Hijiri Byakuren]] who appointed her as captain of her [[palanquin ship|ship]]. After Byakuren was sealed, Murasa and her fellow disciples [[Toramaru Shou]] and [[Kumoi Ichirin]] moved in to save her using the same ship she entrusted to them. Usually seen holding a [[hishaku]].

She has been memetically referred to as Captain Murasa.
light rays:
Light rays are streams of light that travel through gaps in between objects. (See post #2619062)

[[Spotlight]] is the a beam of light that shines down over somebody. This usually happens during a stage performance as a focal point for spectators or when a character is down at least on one's knee for some reason. (See post #3819066)

[[Sunlight]] when the light is from the sun. (See post #3879830)

For tagging purposes, keep in mind that a particular image may satisfy one or more of the specific terms mentioned above.
night: The time of the day when it is [[dark]]. The [[sky]] is usually [[black]] or dark [[blue]].
bottle: A typically glass or plastic container with a narrow neck and opening made to store liquids.
hood down: Wearing a hooded garment without the [[hood]] on the head (as opposed to wearing the [[hood up]]). The hood must be visible for this tag to apply. If there's no hood at all on a character normally seen with a hood, consider the [[no headwear]] tag instead. [[Removing hood]] can apply when the hood is shown being thrown back or removed by the wearer.
piercing:
An opening created in the body in which [[jewelry]] is worn.

This tag is for face and body piercings. This tag should not be used for ordinary [[earrings]] worn in the earlobes.
muscular:
For the actual muscle tissue under the skin (such as seen in [[anatomy]] pictures), please use [[exposed muscle]]. For unknown pink tissue that doesn’t have the lines seen in muscle tissue, use [[flesh]].

Noticeably developed musculature that must have come from extensive training, body building or otherwise. The body has visually "bulked up" and has become obviously thicker.

* [b] Comparison with [[toned]][/b]
Details like bulkiness of the [[thick arms |arms]], [[thick neck|neck]], [[strongman waist|waist]] and [[broad shoulders]] are a good way to distinguish between [[toned]] and [[muscular]] builds.

[i]Do not use [/i][[pectorals]] size alone as a determinant for this tag. It is common in artwork to draw them disproportionately to the rest of the body, especially with [[manboobs]] etc.

colored pubic hair:
Unnaturally colored [[pubic hair]], such as white, green, pink, or red. Don't use this tag if the hair is black, brown, or any other natural color and if the pubic hair is barely noticeable.

Use [[mismatched pubic hair]] when the pubic hair color doesn't match the color of hair on the head.

legs: When legs are the main focus of the image. If the legs in question are not on full display, [i]not just [[thighs]][/i], please refrain from using this tag.
statue: A lifelike free-standing [[sculpture]] usually depicting a human, animal, or deity. Statues memorializing specific historical figures are particularly common. Statues vary in scale from life-size to colossal proportions. Small-scale statues are known as [[statuette|statuettes]].
sailor collar: A sailor-style collar, a two-color collar (usually blue and white or black and white) with one or more stripes near its edges. Often paired with a [[neckerchief]].
kesa: Kesa is a surplice, an oblong piece of ornamental cloth worn over the [[robe]] ("Kasaya":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kasaya_(clothing)]) by a Buddhist priest.
zipper:
A popular device - designed with specially shaped metal or plastic teeth -  for temporarily joining two edges of [[jacket|fabric]]. It's also on other daily used items: [[suitcase|suitcases]], [[backpack|backpacks]], [[handbag|handbags]] etc.

Tag is used on zippers that stand out in an image, because the artist intended it that way by detail or fashion.

UK English equivalent is [b]zip[/b].
racing miku:
An alternate version of [[Hatsune Miku]] that serves as the mascot for [[GoodSmile Racing]].

[[Hatsune Miku]] receives a new design in a [[race queen]] theme for each racing season since 2009. The designs are officially acknowledged as "Racing Miku" (レーシングミク). The real life race queens for GoodSmile are known as the "Racing Miku Supporters" and wear outfits based on the Racing Miku design of the year.

The 2009 derivative is the only version of the Racing Miku derivatives which did not have an official illustration as per her release, though it was featured in merchandise for that season and new official arts have been given later on. The unveiling of the Racing Miku derivatives only became a feature from the 2010 season onwards. All merchandise related to Good Smile Racing featuring Miku prior to the 2010 season, with the exception of the 2009 Racing Miku figurine, features Miku in her normal attire.
beach: Where the land meets the [[water]]. Beaches are flat and made of sand, gravel, or small stones - when rocky, paved, or sheer cliff, see [[shore]].
cyborg:
An organism that is made up of both [b]cyb[/b]ernetic and [b]org[/b]anic components. In anime, this generally refers to humans that have been altered to be partially [[robot]]ic.

It can be difficult to tell a cyborg apart from an [[android]], especially when dealing with [[original]] characters and those whose origins are unknown. In cases like these, one should examine any visible robotic components. If they appear to be added-on or function as [[prosthesis|prosthetics]], that character is likely a cyborg. If you are unable to determine whether the character is a cyborg or purely robotic, it's best to tag them as [[android]] until more information can be found.
hand on headwear:
When a character touches or holds a [[hat]] that they are currently wearing with one hand.

If they aren't wearing it, use [[holding unworn hat]] instead.
sailor dress:
Dresses that have most elements of sailor uniforms, such as a [[sailor collar]] or [[neckerchief]]. Sailor dresses may be depicted as a [[school uniform]] or casual wear.

Sailor dresses are distinct from [[serafuku]] in that they are a one-piece garment, whereas serafuku consist of a shirt and a skirt or shorts.
bubble skirt: A type of [[skirt]] where the hem is tucked back under at the bottom to create a 'bubble' effect. Popular in the 1950s, 1980s, and the mid-2000s. Good examples are [[cure muse (yellow)|Cure Muse]], [[Medicine Melancholy]], [[Hata no Kokoro]] and [[Kaname Madoka]]'s dresses.
karakasa obake:
An umbrella [[traditional youkai]]. It has [[one-eyed|one eye]], a long [[tongue]] and a single foot. Also known as 唐傘小僧 ([i]Karakasa Kozou[/i], Karakasa Boy).

"Karakasa" is another word for 和傘, a traditional Japanese [[oil-paper umbrella]]. The word means "Chinese-style umbrella" in Japanese because it originated in China.
music: When a character is [[playing instrument|playing an instrument]] or [[singing]]. See [[audible music]] for posts that contain actual music.
tongue:
When the tongue is decently visible, well defined, or particularly prominent.

For tongues appearing out of the mouth, see [[tongue out]].

For particularly long tongues, see [[long tongue]].
loose belt:
A belt worn loosely, as an accessory, rather than to hold up another piece of clothing.

Use [[open belt]] for an unbuckled belt.

sketch:
A hasty or undetailed drawing or painting often made as a preliminary study. Traits include rough lines, [[monochrome]] or basic coloring, and left over structural shapes.

Not all pictures with these traits are considered sketches, such as post #2721361 and post #2722170. Posts with proper use of the sketch tag are post #2720851 and post #2722791.

Abbreviated on Pixiv as "rkgk", which comes from the Japanese word for sketch (落書き, [i]rakugaki[/i]). Not all pictured tagged as "sketch" by the artist should be tagged as [[sketch]] on Danbooru. The picture must look like a sketch for it to apply. [b]Translated tags have been removed from this wiki, because artists tend to use this tag in a very misleading way.[/b]

Sketches are not sufficient reasons for flagging. See [[howto:flag]].

Not to be confused with [[sketching]], which is used for when a character within the image is sketching an image themselves.
lips: The fleshy folds that surround the opening of the mouth.
huge nipples: Nipples which appear longer or thicker than normal, [[covered_nipples|clothed]] or [[nipples|exposed]]. A good general rule: if it's as long or twice as thick as a thumb, it qualifies for the tag.
layered sleeves: When a character is wearing multiple layers of sleeves.
completely nude:
Wearing no clothing from the neck down. This means that [[glasses]], [[hat]]s, and other such clothing items do not count against the tag.

[[Jewelry]] and small accessories such as [[wristband]]s, [[anklet]]s, [[tail ribbon]]s, etc, don't count against the tag.

Towels are fine as long as they are held, and aren't tied to the body or adherent to the body (eg. post #4065442). If the second case applies, please tag as [[naked towel]] or [[nude cover]].

[[Naked chocolate]] or other such fluids poured on a body do not count against the tag.

[[Rope]]s and [[belt]]s do count against the tag. Even if used in [[BDSM]].

Make sure you can see their crotch or lower, otherwise see [[nude]].
holding:
Someone is holding an object.

This tag should only be used for items you can pick up and carry with your hands. Don't use for holding body parts (like [[holding hands]], or [[breast hold|holding someone's breasts]]), or for holding clothing being worn (like a [[skirt hold]]), or for holding things with something other than the hands (like a [[mouth hold]], [[holding with feet]], or [[holding with tail]]).

To search for something specific being held, just use two tags together, like this: {{holding popsicle}}. Note that these searches don't always work well. Many posts of a search like {{holding hat}} are people [i]wearing hats[/i] while [i]holding other things[/i], so it would be ineffective to see people [i]holding hats[/i]. Hence the existence of specialized tags.
short over long sleeves: Someone who layers a short-sleeved garment over a long-sleeved garment to get a nice color (or pattern) combo. This type of layering was largely popular in the 1990s.

宝塔 ([i]Houtou[/i])

yasaka kanako:
The "Avatar of Mountains and Lakes".

Final boss of [[Touhou]]'s [[Mountain of Faith]], and later made playable in [[Sunken Fossil World]]. In canon appearance, she has short purple hair, wears a mirror on her chest, has a circular [[shimenawa]] floating behind her back. Her weapon is the [[onbashira]].

She is the goddess of the Moriya Shrine after defeating [[Moriya Suwako]] a long time ago, her symbol is a snake as signified by the [[shimenawa]], which she adopted to symbolize her victory over the frog-themed goddess Suwako. Some artists take the snake symbolism much further, such as depicting Kanako with [[slit pupils]] (as in the [[aged down]] [[snake-eyed Kanako]]), a [[long tongue|long]] and/or [[forked tongue]], and even as a [[lamia]]. Her true power is dominion over wind and rain. Due to her estimated age and imposing appearance, she is jokingly a member of the "Old Maids Alliance":/pools/1053.

bob cut: A [[short hair|short haircut]] in which a weighted area is left to fall between the ears and chin, can often include [[blunt ends]].
hat ornament: An accessory worn on a [[hat]] for decoration or ornamentation purposes.

sunflower:
A native flowering plant from the Americas.  The common sunflower is most recognizable by their single large yellow apical "flower," with an initially greenish center that turns yellow-brown and then blackish as it matures.  They typically grow to heights of around 3 meters (10 feet) with record plants reach heights of 9+ meters (30+ feet). Sunflowers are grown for various purposes such as for food, cooking oil, livestock feed, and decoration. 

Domestic sunflowers come in a variety of colors beyond the common yellow, with colors such as cream color, gold, orange, red, mahogany, and chocolate brown.  While the common types only feature a singular apical flower (one that grows at the tip of the central stem), there are also varieties that grow many additional branching flowers.  The large blooms of the sunflower while commonly called a "flower" is in fact a "flower head," a structure composed of many smaller flowers (florets) that together appear as one single flower.

Sunflowers and their relatives are heliotropic while they're developing, meaning that the plants will turn following the direction of the sun during the day.  As they get closer to maturing, the plant stiffen and lose it's ability to track the sun. Due to their heliotropic nature, most plants will mature locked facing toward the East, the direction of the rising sun.

lantern:
A portable light source, designed to be carried or hung up, typically with an enclosure to protect it from the wind when used [[outdoors]].

Traditional lanterns use a [[candle]] or a wick dipped in oil, while modern lanterns use battery-powered lights.

For fixed [[outdoors]] lighting, use [[stone lantern]], [[wooden lantern]], or [[lamppost]] accordingly. Despite the name, the former two do not fall under this tag.
gag:
An object placed in or over the mouth to restrict speech, such as a [[ball gag]]. Typically used in [[bdsm]]. 

A character who is gagged, whether by a purpose built gag or an improvised gag, should also be tagged as [[gagged]].

Not to be confused with [[gagging]].
wiffle gag: A type of [[gag]] with holes like a wiffle ball for easier breathing or to force the wearer to [[saliva|drool]], commonly seen as a [[ball gag]].

suit:

sailor:
Also known as a seaman, mariner, or seafarer, a person who navigates water-borne vessels or assists as a crew member in their operation and maintenance.

tatara kogasa:

A [i]karakasa[/i] youkai who frequently tries (in vain) to surprise humans. She carries her [[purple umbrella|purple]] [[karakasa obake]] with a [[tongue]] almost always sticking out, although there is some debate as to whether the girl or the umbrella (or both) is the real Kogasa. Fanworks often depict her under the mercy of [[Kochiya Sanae]] due to the latter's scathing words against her back in UFO.

Due to similarities in her style of dress to [[Kazami Yuuka]] (designated by [[ZUN (artist)|]] as "youkai moe"), along with her being perceived as a highly moe character in her own right, Kogasa is often referred to by fans as "the new youkai moe."
trigger discipline:
[[holding gun|Holding a gun]] while keeping one's finger away from the trigger. The opposite of [[finger on trigger]].

Characters doing so will usually have their trigger finger resting on the trigger guard or body of the [[gun|firearm]], so as to avoid an accidental trigger pull.

This tag does [i]not[/i] apply when:

* The character has their [[finger on trigger|finger on the trigger]] on inside the trigger guard.
* the character is [[holding gun|holding the gun]] by someplace other than the main grip (e.g. by the barrel or carry handle)

It is possible for someone [[dual wielding]] to practice trigger discipline with one hand and not the other, e.g. post #1188474.
teeth:
Small, whitish structures found inside one's jaw. Teeth are used to bite, to break down food before they are swallowed, and many other functions including self-defense.

In most drawings the teeth would usually be excluded from the picture unless it is a [[grin]], [[crying]], [[biting]] or others. Use this tag when the teeth are prominent.
lucy (cyberpunk):
A character from the [[Cyberpunk Edgerunners]] anime, set in the [[Cyberpunk 2077]] universe.

Lucy is portrayed as a woman with [[short hair|short]], [[multicolored hair]] with [[short hair with long locks|long locks]], [[asymmetrical bangs]] and [[multicolored eyes]], [[medium breasts]]. Usually depicted wearing a [[blue leotard|blue]] [[highleg leotard]] over [[white shorts]], [[blue pantyhose]] with [[hip vent]] and [[knee boots]]. Often [[smoking|smokes]].
official alternate hair length:

[b]Do not[/b] use this tag with [[alternate hair length]], the tags are mutually exclusive.
expressionless: When a character's face lacks any emotion or expression. Different from [[serious]] because there is a reason for anger or determination, such as a battle or a death. Here, the character is stoic for no apparent reason.
injury: When a character has sustained a hit from something (melee [[weapon]], [[gun]] bullet, [[clenched hand]], [[battle]], [[falling]] object, [[tripping]], speeding vehicle, disastrous weather, and other coincidences). Going through such trauma will lead one to exhibit [[pain]].
fishnets:
A material with an open, diamond shaped knit. It's most often used as a material for stockings, tights or bodystockings and is usually black. Ironically unsuited for catching fish.

Do not confuse with [[fishing net]].
navel:

Use [[no shoes]] instead if the character is not wearing [[shoes]], but is wearing [[socks]], [[thighhighs]], or other legwear.
restrained: A character who is prevented from moving by something or someone.
choker:

It's sometimes also worn in [[BDSM]] in place of a more traditional [[collar]].

Not to be confused with [[choking on object|choking]], which is a type of [[asphyxiation]], or with a [[collar]], which is usually made of thicker material and not as tight-fitting.
watermark:
An image containing text or a [[logo]] superimposed on top of the image. Typically to identify the owner/creator of the work and/or prevent the image from being counterfeited. Some watermarks are also deliberately placed as a "paywall" on "samples" of "[[paid reward]]" images.

Posts with watermarks added by [[third-party watermark|third-parties]] (anyone other than the artist) should not be uploaded.

Add [[watermark grid]] if it spans over a majority/the whole image. Add [[too many watermarks]] if it's in excess as to be noticeable from the thumbnail.
spread anus: A person's [[anus]] held wide open, exposing their rectal cavity.
neckerchief:
A piece of cloth tied into two separate pieces resembling neckties.

Often seen as a part of a [[serafuku]] or other clothing featuring such a [[sailor collar]].
red collar:
A [[collar]] that is colored [[red]].

This is for standalone [[collar]]s not part of a shirt. Do not use for [[collared shirt]]s, [[red sailor collar]]s, or other similar clothing.
uncensored:
An image that has not been [[censored]] by the artist. See [[decensored]] for images that have been decensored by a [[third-party edit]].

This tag applies only to genitalia, sex acts, body fluids, or other things that would normally be censored. It does not apply to [[nipples]], or to body parts that aren't fully visible. Note that this tag is mutually exclusive from [[censored]], and that both tags can be applied if one of the chracter's genitalia is left uncensored.

In Japan, it is illegal to draw uncensored genitalia if they are to be published publicly for domestic distribution. Some artists skirt around this law by applying censorship that is easy to remove, or by applying [[pointless censoring|pointless censorship]] that barely hides the censored body part. Others maintain a non-Japanese presence to bypass Japanese laws altogether and distribute uncensored versions of their work. It is also noted that some censorship also doubles as a paywall or sample work of sorts, with the uncensored version available in an artists' donation page, such as Patreon, Fanbox and others.
covered mouth:
When a character's mouth is covered from view. The mouth should be covered, but items don't always have to touch the face (i.e. post #4273544).

Items covering the mouth may include but are not limited to: garments (scarves, masks, high collars), objects (books, boxes, pillows), or parts of the body (hands, fingers).
maid apron: An [[apron]] worn by a [[maid]]. Usually decorated with [[frilled apron|frills]] and long enough to cover from the chest down to the thighs or knees.
open jacket:

wrist grab: This tag has been moved to [[holding_another's_wrist]].
grin:

[[Standing]] with the body's weight on one leg, with the hip cocked out.

Contrapposto is an art theory term from the Italian word, meaning "counterpoise."
short hair:

brown pants: Any style of [[pants]] that are colored [[brown]].
collared shirt:

layered dress: A [[dress]] that consists of multiple layers of fabric.
dark skin: Skin that is darker in tone than the usual Caucasian/East Asian skintone. Characters usually have this skintone naturally, but sometimes have dark skin due to a [[tan]], alternate coloring, etc.
ring: [[Jewelry]] consisting of a circlet of precious metal (often set with jewels), usually worn on the finger.
no nipples: When a character's bare chest is fully visible and unobscured (e.g. by [[fog]]), but their [[nipples]] (where expected) are absent.

horizon:
The horizon is the border between [[earth (planet)|]] and [[sky]]. As the horizon is usually obscured by trees, mountains, buildings, etc., it is most visible in settings dominated by the [[ocean]] or other featureless terrain.

When the outline of a city is visible over the horizon, this is known as a [[skyline]].

If the horizon is tilted with respect to the picture frame, the result is a [[dutch angle]].
cum in pussy:

leotard:

They are most often worn by acrobats, [[gymnastics|gymnasts]], [[dancer]]s, and circus performers.

They also influenced the [[one-piece swimsuit]] design, but swimsuits should not be tagged as leotards.

If the leotard does cover at least the upper legs, do not use this tag. Use [[bodysuit]] instead.

Compared to the uniformity of a [[checkered|check]] pattern, [[plaid]] features distinct irregularity in the width of its lines, and the colors used may not be "divided neatly":[https://imgur.com/a/k4DwICA] by said lines.

hijiri byakuren:
[[Touhou]] character. Her title is The Sealed Great Magician. She was introduced into the series as the final boss of [[Undefined Fantastic Object]].

A Buddhist magician whose younger brother [[Hijiri Myouren|Myouren]]'s traumatic death drove her to seek agelessness, as well as a pacifist who believes in equality between humans and youkai. Once sealed in Makai by humans (where many think she made friends with and learned spellcards from [[Shinki (touhou)|]]), but was freed during Undefined Fantastic Object by her followers [[Toramaru Shou]], [[Murasa Minamitsu]] and [[Kumoi Ichirin]].

She has [[long_hair|long]] [[gradient hair]] that goes from [[purple_hair|purple]] to [[brown_hair|brown]]. Many fans were confused if her hair was either gradient or if the purple was just from the lighting coming from her [[Sorcerer's Sutra Scroll|scroll]]. ZUN has confirmed that her hair is indeed naturally gradient. All clothes she is depicted wearing are always criss-crossed. In [[Hopeless Masquerade]] she is depicted with an [[ajirogasa]] hat and a [[necklace]] of [[prayer beads]]. In [[Urban Legend in Limbo]] she gets a [[bikesuit]] along with her own motorcycle.

See also [[namusanbou]] which tends to be associated with her because of her stage 6 dialogue.

puffy nipples: Nipples and most often areolae that are noticeably swollen beyond the regular curvature of the breast.
shirt: A piece of clothing worn on the upper half of a body.
gohei:
[i]Gohei[/i] (御幣), aka [i]onbe[/i] (御幣) or [i]heisoku[/i] (幣束). 

A wooden wand traditionally decorated with [[shide]] (zigzag paper streamers), though in the past it was made with rectangular strips of paper. It is used for [[Shinto]] rituals to cleanse negative energy or bless.

Notable characters with gohei include [[Hakurei Reimu]], [[Kochiya Sanae]] (who is often seen using an old-fashioned gohei with a single rectangular strip of paper on the end) and [[Yae Miko]] (who uses the more modern, zigzag paper strip gohei).
jumping: The act of propelling oneself into the air from a surface, usually through the flexion and sudden muscular extension of the [[legs]].
mobile suit:
[b]Mobile Suit[/b], often abbreviated as [b]MS[/b], is the name of the [[mecha]] in the [[Gundam]] series. It basically refers to any (mostly) humanoid giant robot (standing from about 15 to 20+ meters tall) that is piloted by a human soldier (aside from [[G Gundam]], which uses the term [b]Mobile Fighter[/b]).

Most mobile suits are humanoid-shaped, though there are some which are not, such as the [[BuCUE]] and [[LaGOWE]] from [[Gundam SEED]].

This term was first introduced in the first episode of the original Gundam series, [[Mobile Suit Gundam]] from 1979. [[Tomino Yoshiyuki]], creator and writer of the series, explained that the concept of a manned robot was inspired by the [[super robot]] shows of the 1970s that began with the [[Mazinger Z]] anime from 1972. The name is also a tribute to the [[Mobile Infantry]], a fictional military organization of [[space marine]]s that uses [[power armor]] in the novel [[Starship Troopers]] from 1959.
utility pole:
A utility pole is a column or post, frequently made of wood, used to support overhead [[power lines]] and various other public utilities, such as electrical cable, fiber optic cable, and related equipment such as [[transformer|transformers]] and street lights. 

Depending on the application they may be referred by various names, such as transmission pole, telephone pole, telecommunication pole, power pole, telegraph pole, and telegraph post.

Should not be confused with a [[transmission towe

crying with eyes open: When [[tears]] are being shed from an open eye or eyes.
sidelocks: Long locks of hair growing directly in front of the ears (AKA earlocks).
closed mouth: The opposite of [[open mouth]], where the character is keeping their lips together and not showing any interior portion of the mouth.
cityscape: [[Scenery]] that represents the physical aspects of a [[city]] or urban area.
lightning:
An atmospheric discharge of electricity accompanied by [[thunder]], which typically occurs during thunderstorms.

This tag is only for naturally occurring lightning in the sky. Electrical discharges generated by a character or weapon should use the [[electricity]] tag instead.

For the little zig-zag symbol, use [[lightning bolt symbol]].
double-breasted: Describes a type of buttoning usually found on outerwear with two columns of [[buttons]] and flaps that overlap rather than meeting at the middle.
underwear: Clothes worn under clothes, most often directly on top of the skin. This includes [[bra]]s, [[panties]], [[lingerie]], and [[male underwear]].

own hands together:
When a single character touches their hands together.

See [[holding hands]] for when two or more characters' hands are touching.
anger vein:
A symbol used to represent [[angry|anger]] or [[annoyed|annoyance]]. It consists of three or four curved lines in a cross shape, representing a bulging vein or artery, like so: 💢.

It usually appears on or floating near the forehead or fist; however, it can also appear on other body parts, or even as a [[spoken anger vein]] in dialogue.
holding own arm:
The act of holding one's own arm.
For a character holding on to another character's arm, use [[holding another's arm]].

A [[building]] for residential dwelling.

vaginal object insertion:
When any inanimate object, such as a [[vibrator]], [[dildo]], a [[carrot]], etc., is inserted into the [[vaginal|vagina]].

This does not apply to a [[penis]] being inserted; use the [[sex]] tag for that. It also does not apply to other body parts, such as [[fingering|fingers]], being inserted. It also does not apply to [[tentacles]] - use [[tentacle sex]] for that.
sword:
A bladed [[weapon]] designed for cutting or thrusting. They are typically composed of a hilt and a blade with one or two edges that can be straight or curved; most, but not all, swords have a pointed tip. The hilt, in turn, consists of a guard, a grip, and in most designs a pommel. The guard can be a crossguard like in a typical knight's sword, a disc like the [i]tsuba[/i] of a katana, or some more complex design.

It is a weapon strongly associated with elite warriors such as [[knight]]s and [[samurai]].
thick thighs:
[[Thighs]] that are thicker than "normal."

Don't add this tag just because thighs are visible. The actual size must be large to use this tag. In general, be careful if you have a character with either a very [[fat]] waist that doesn't require the thighs to be very thick, or a very [[skinny|thin]] waist that requires the thighs to be very thick, if each thigh is about the same size as the character's waist.
style parody:
Art drawn in the style of another artist.

When an artist imitates the style of a particular era, but not a specific artist, use [[retro artstyle]] or a specific decade style tag (e.g. [[1990s (style)]]) instead. When an artist imitates the style of [[official art]], use [[official style]] instead.
crossover:
A crossover is when two or more characters from unrelated copyrights are shown together in one scene. 

Crossover should not be confused with [[parody]]. A parody implies mimicking a scene or dialogue from another series, with the intention of being humorous.

One character [[cosplay|cosplaying]] as a character from another series does not normally qualify as a crossover.

Use [[songover]] for crossovers between multiple songs or other musical compositions, seen commonly with [[Vocaloid]] songs.
sitting: The butt resting on a surface (often a [[chair]], [[couch]], or [[bench]]), possibly in addition to the legs or feet. For a position with the knees on the floor, use [[kneeling]] (except with seiza below).
foreshortening: Foreshortening is the effect that an object is pointing at the viewer, by making it "shorter" than it really is (and usually enlarging the object). Getting this right is one of the "holy grails" of artists. Technically, all drawings that include the illusion of depth have foreshortening, so only use this tag if the foreshortening is a strong element of the image. Not to be confused with [[depth of field]], which refers to blurry, out-of-focus portions of an image. An image can contain both, but not necessarily. Examples of foreshortening without [[depth of field]]: * !post #6795996 * !post #705217 Examples of foreshortening with [[depth of field]]: * !post #385277: [[depth of field]] in the foreground * !post #5749171: [[depth of field]] in the background
headband:
A strap [b]worn across the forehead[/b], such as a sweatband, a strip of cloth worn during martial arts or athletic events, or a piece of ninja armor (however apocryphal). While a headband may be used to keep hair out of the eyes, it is usually worn under at least part of the hair. Headbands often end with a long tail trailing behind the head where they are tied. 

For a band [b]worn over the top of the head[/b], that is principally used to maintain a hair style, see [[hairband]].
ass visible through thighs: When you can see the [[ass|butt]] cheeks peeking through between the [[thighs]] of a character who is facing the viewer.
sailor hat: A hat worn by sailors in the navy, or some form thereof. Typically round, flat and without a brim or visor. Often features a ribbon with the name of the sailor's ship tied around the base of the cap.
floating:
Moving or hovering in the air, seemingly without the help of an outside propulsion system (i.e wings).

For the act of floating in water, use [[afloat]].
red footwear: Deprecated tag. Use one of the tags below instead.
frogtie: A [[bondage]] position wherein the ankle is bound to the thigh or wrist, with the effect of keeping the subject's legs folded and typically apart. The arms are also usually tied behind the back.
black footwear: Deprecated tag. Use one of the tags below instead.
blue serafuku: A [[serafuku]] that has both its [[shirt]] and [[skirt]] colored blue. The [[neckerchief]] and [[sailor collar]] do not count towards this tag.
shorts pull: [[Shorts]] that are pulled down from their normal fitting position.
grey hair:
Hair that is colored grey.

Due to the subjective nature of color judgment and other factors (such as differences in color displayed on monitors) there is potential overlap between this tag and the [[blue hair]], [[aqua hair]], and [[purple hair]] tags, generally in the lighter shades of those colors. Grey is also often used to shade [[white hair]]. It is a good idea to compare the hair in question to how other white things, namely white clothes, are shaded. If the shading on the hair resembles how white clothing is shaded, it is likely white, and not grey.
spider web print: Clothing or an object that has a [[spider web]] printed on it.
armpit hair: Hair that grows from the [[armpits]].  Usually [[shaving|shaved off]] from women.
frog hair ornament:
A hair ornament in the shape of a frog.

Most commonly seen on danbooru as worn by [[Kochiya Sanae]] of the [[Touhou]] series, along with another [[snake hair ornament|snake-shaped one]]. In her case it is generally assumed to be a symbol of [[Moriya Suwako]].
shirayuki chiyo:
[b]Shirayuki Chiyo[/b] is an [[idol]] appearing in [[idolmaster cinderella girls|THE IDOLM@STER Cinderella Girls]]. Along with [[Kurosaki Chitose]], she was one of the first characters to debut already voiced, as well as the first to appear in [[idolmaster cinderella girls starlight stage|Starlight Stage]] before Mobamas. She was added to Mobamas on April 5, 2019.

Although she has an edgy personality, she is cataloged as a cute type idol. Voiced by [[Sekiguchi Risa]].
cat tail: Use this tag when a character has a [[cat]]-like [[tail]].
twin braids:
A hairstyle that consists of two [[braid]]ed lengths of hair.

This can be the hair in front of the ears, like [[sidelocks]], or the hair behind the ears, like [[twintails]].

If the [[braid]]s are tied low, below ear-level, they're [[low twin braids]]. If the back of the hair is tied into two full-length braids, then they're also [[twintails]].
smoke: A suspension of airborne particulate and gases as the result of incomplete [[burning|combustion]] or chemical reaction.
blue hair:
Hair that is colored blue.

Due to the subjective nature of color judgment and other factors (such as the lighting on the characters) there is an overlap between this tag, and the [[aqua hair]] tags. Due to blue often being the undertone used for [[black hair]] and [[white hair]], there is an additional overlap with those tags too.
arms behind head:
When a character has both arms behind their own head.

If only one arm is behind their head, use [[arm behind head]] instead.

If the character has their arms behind another person's head, use [[arms around neck]] instead.
all fours:
Hands and knees on the floor like a standing four-legged animal. Refers more to the posture really, so at least one hand and one knee or foot on the floor, with the body itself off the ground. If both knees are off the ground, it's [[bear position]].

Not to be confused with [[prostration]].
wing collar:
A collar with folded-down corners, which form the "wings".

Note that "wing collar" on Danbooru has a different meaning. For tagging purposes, this tag refers to collars with large rectangular folds. For collars traditionally known as "wing collar", which are winged just near the tips, use [[wingtip collar]] instead.
serafuku:
The [[school uniform]] with a [[sailor collar|sailor-style collar]] worn by Japanese schoolgirls in middle school and high school. The standard uniform consists of a white [[blouse]], a [[pleated skirt]], and a red [[neckerchief]], but there are as many variations as there are stars in the sky. 
 
Serafukus are commonly worn with a [[ribbon]] or [[bow]] in lieu of the traditional neckerchief. The line between "neckerchief" and "bow" is blurry, as the bows worn with serafukus often aren't actually dedicated bows or [[bowtie|bowties]], but rather a neckerchief tied into a bow instead of its intended scarf-like shape.
 
A serafuku always includes a [[skirt]]. If a sailor-style top is paired with shorts or another bottom, [[sailor shirt]] should be used instead. In fact, sailor suits with shorts are the older, original style: in the Victorian and Edwardian eras, they were used as boys' suits, from which then the girls' uniform with a skirt was derived.

For colored serafuku tags, both the [[shirt]] and [[skirt]] must match in color to apply, but not the neckwear or [[sailor collar]].

[[Sailor dress]]es should not be tagged as serafuku.
frilled sleeves: Sleeves, [[detached sleeves|detached]] or otherwise, that end in [[frills]].
jewelry: Any decorative adornments worn on a person made from various metals, [[gem|gemstones]], shells and beads. Its purpose is to enhance the wearer's appearance, although there are practical-usage pieces such as medic-alert bracelets and military dog tags.
katana:
A type of Japanese [[sword]] ([i]nihontou[/i]), and is often called a "samurai sword" because of its historical associations with feudal-era Japan.

The katana is characterized by its distinctive appearance: a curved, slender, single-edged blade, circular or squared [[tsuba (guard)|guard]], and long grip to accommodate two hands (the hilt is often given a distinctive wrapping of silk known as [i][[tsuka-ito|tsukaito]][/i]).

The sword preceding the katana is called a [[tachi (weapon)|]]. The general difference between a tachi and a katana is how they are carried. The tachi is suspended from one’s waist belt with the cutting edge facing down, while the katana is thrust through the waist belt, edge facing up. Also, in general the tachi is more curved and longer than the katana.

anal:
Anal penetration. This includes anal [[sex]], [[anal fingering]], [[anal object insertion|anal insertion]] of [[sex toy]]s, anal [[tentacle rape|tentacle penetration]], and any other type of anal penetration.

If, and only if, a [[penis]] is inserted there, then the image should also be tagged [[sex]].
no humans:
No human or human-like characters are visible in the picture.

Human-like characters include [[android]]s and sentient [[humanoid robot]]s, [[traditional youkai]], living [[doll]]s, [[monster girl]]s, [[furry|furries]], and anything else that looks or acts human (i.e. humanoids such as [[Gardevoir]]).
producer (idolmaster):
The Producer is the unseen player character of [[idolmaster|THE iDOLM@STER]] series. While never shown to the player in the games, he is generally implied to be an adult male in his early twenties. In illustrations he is nearly always depicted wearing a [[suit]] and [[necktie]], where as his face is obscured, missing, or symbolically replaced altogether.

In addition to the in-game character, the title of Producer is also used to refer to fans as a whole, and for fans of a particular [[idol]]. In the latter case, they are usually referred to by the idol's name first, with Producer being shortened to just "P" (e.g. HarukaP, RankoP, and so on.).

This tag serves as both an umbrella tag for the character's various incarnations as well as the non-specific form from the games or fan materials.
pink dress: A [[dress]] that is mainly [[pink]] in color.
ufo:
Short for "Unidentified Flying Object". Stereotypical depiction of an [[alien]] [[spacecraft]] originated from various description of the supposed spotting of alien spacecraft during the 1950 - 1970s "UFO craze" around the Americas.

The most common depiction of UFO are a "[[flying saucer]]", a disc-shaped spacecraft often with a glass canopy for its occupant. Though other types such as a sphere and a cigar-shaped UFO is also often depicted.
cat: A domesticated feline mammal. This tag can also be used for cat-related things like [[stuffed cat]]s, cat demons/monsters, and [[cathead|bodiless cat heads]].
elbow gloves: Elbow [[gloves]] (alternatively opera gloves, evening gloves, or over-the-elbow gloves) are a type of formal glove that reach near or beyond the elbow.
\\m/:
The 🤟 hand gesture. The thumb, index, and pinkie fingers are held out, while the middle and ring fingers touch the palm of the hand.

Not to be confused with [[\n/]] (🤘), where the thumb is held down instead of extended out.

In anime, it is well known for being part of the [[Sailor Moon]]'s famous [[Tsuki ni kawatte oshioki yo]] ("I'll punish you") pose, for [[Ranka Lee]]'s dance move in [[Macross Frontier]] while singing the song [[Seikan Hikou]], and for the association with [[Yazawa Nico]]'s catchphrase, [[nico nico nii]].

In American sign language it's known as the "I Love You" sign, after a combination of the ASL signs for the letters I, L, and Y.
censored:
When parts of the image (typically graphic or sensitive contents such as sexual organs, gore, or offensive symbolism) are obscured, typically to comply with censorship laws.

On Danbooru, this typically encompasses various Japanese pornographic materials that were censored as a result of the Japanese law. Techniques that prevent viewing sexual parts, usually [[pussy|vaginas]], [[penis]]es and [[dildo]]s but occasionally [[nipples]]. Note that the [[anus]] is not usually considered a sexual part in Japanese censorship.  

Common forms include [[mosaic censoring|mosaics]], [[bar censor|black bars]], [[blur censor|blurs]], mysterious [[light censor|white lights]], inverted colors, shaded bars, and the infamous [[invisible penis]]. [[Tentacles]] or phallic objects are commonly used to resemble genitals and generally don't need to be censored, though the point of intercourse with a vagina does. 

For obstructions that are [i]internal[/i] to the picture, like a lock of [[hair_censor|hair]] that just happens to cover the genitals, use the tag [[convenient censoring]] instead of censored.
heart-shaped pupils:
When a character's pupils are shaped like [[heart]]s. Often a sign of being [[lovestruck]] or experiencing sexual pleasure.

See [[heart in eye]] for when there are hearts inside the eyes, but the pupils aren't shaped like hearts. See [[heart-shaped eyes]] for when a character's entire eyes are literal hearts, like a cartoon character in love.
hooded jacket:
A [[jacket]] with an attached [[hood]]. Oftentimes features a [[drawstring]], sometimes a pullover, often a zip-up.

[b]Not to be confused on Danbooru with [[hoodie]][/b], which is a hooded sweater.
short sleeves: Sleeves that don't reach beyond the elbows or cover the forearms.
head back: When someone is tilting their head backwards so that the area under the [[chin]] is visible to the viewer. In normal circumstances, this is seen when looking upwards at the sky. In sexual circumstances, this may be seen during an [[orgasm]].
wide-eyed: Having the eyes completely opened, to the point that the sclera is visible all the way around the iris.
socks: A piece of clothing worn on the feet beneath the [[shoes]]. Socks can be anywhere from [[ankle socks|ankle high]] to [[kneehighs|knee high]].
hood: A covering for the head and neck, either separate or attached to a cloak, coat, or the like.
looking to the side: When a character's gaze is directed to something off to their side. Most commonly are eyes looking 90 degrees across the shoulder, but may also include up to 45 degrees facing in either direction. [[Looking to the side]] is relative to the character's front, not the viewer's perspective. If the eyes are directed more than 45 degrees backwards use [[looking back]] instead. If the character looks to the side without moving their head, combine with [[sideways glance]]. Not to be confused with [[averting eyes]], where someone deliberately diverts their gaze from the viewer/others out of [[embarrassed|embarrassment]] , [[angry|anger]], [[annoyed|annoyance]], etc.
closed eyes: When a character has both eyes closed. If one eye is open, use [[one eye closed]].

Both [[legs]] [[bondage|bound]] together with some sort of restraint.

boots:
A type of footwear characterized for their durability. They cover the entire foot as well as the ankle, or even more. They can be made from [[leather]], rubber, or even [[metal]]. Some have steel plating on the end to protect the toes.

Footwear that doesnt cover the whole foot (like [[mary janes]]), footwear that doesn't cover the ankle (like [[oxfords]]), footwear that are less durable (like [[high tops]]) are tagged as [[shoes]].  

So, while high tops cover the ankle, their comparative lack of durability classify them as shoes (most sneakers are made of textiles or soft plastic).

high collar: Clothing that includes a tall collar.
areolae: Deprecated tag. Use one of the tags below instead.
scar on face: A [[scar]] on any part of a character's face.
pink eyes:
A character with pink colored eyes.

Due to the subjective nature of color judgment and other factors (such as the lighting on the characters), there is an overlap between this tag and the [[purple eyes]] and [[red eyes]] tags.
robot: An autonomous mechanical or electronic machine.
sparkle:
A momentary bright shimmer of reflected [[light]], generally [[diamond_(shape)|]]- or [[star (symbol)|]]-shaped, and short-lived. Groups of them tend to appear and vanish in various instances.

[b]Sparkle[/b], [[glint]], and [[diffraction spikes]] all refer to similar patterns of bright lines radiating from a point. They are not clearly differentiated, and usage tends to be context-sensitive. In general:
* [b]Sparkle[/b] is considered the base case. Usually four lines at right angles radiating from a point. Associated with eyes, liquid or particulate matter (e.g. raindrops, snow, sand), or nothing (appearing mid-air). Can appear in large numbers.
* [[Glint]] is associated with solid objects, especially ones which are metallic and/or sharp. Usually appear singly or in small numbers.
* [[Diffraction spikes]] is the technical term for the phenomenon in general, but is used less often. Can be used for more realistic-looking effects or conversely when appearing extremely large and exaggerated. More likely than sparkle and glint to be asymmetric or to have more than four radiating lines.
girl sandwich:
Situation where a person (of any gender) is [[sandwiched]] between two girls.

Referred to as "having a flower in both hands" in Japanese.
bug: An insect, spider, arthropod, or any other similar kind of creature. Bugs are usually invertebrates, with a segmented body, multiple pairs of jointed limbs, and sometimes wings.
light smile: A gentle/subtle smile, similar to that of the [i]Mona Lisa[/i]. This tag is considered distinct from "smile":/wiki_pages?title=smile to help distinguish the two (see topic #6008).
beads: A small piece of glass, stone, or similar material, typically rounded and perforated for threading with others as a [[necklace]], [[bracelet]] or [[rosary]], or for sewing onto fabric.
seagull: Gulls or "seagulls" are sea birds in the family [i]Laridae[/i] other than terns, noddies and skimmers.
deep skin: When the skin is [[grabbing|grabbed]] so deeply that fingertips get lost in it, as though the flesh were gelatin.
vibrator: A typically egg- or bullet-shaped [[sex toy]] that vibrates intensely.  It is especially pleasing when rubbed up against a female's clitoris, often in [[masturbation]].
scar:
A mark left on the skin where a [[deep wound|wound]], [[cuts|cut]], burn, or other [[injury]] healed.

For the character from [[Fullmetal Alchemist]], see [[Scar (FMA)]].

Also not to be confused with the [[FN SCAR]] rifle, or either of the [i][[Girls' Frontline]][/i] [[scar-l (girls' frontline)|characters]] [[scar-h (girls' frontline)|based on it.]]
arms behind back: Both arms swept behind the back in a coy manner, or done forcibly in [[bondage]].
white background:
Backgrounds that are completely or predominantly [[white]] in color. Can also apply to [[gradient background]] in conjunction with another background color.

When completely white and solid, it is also a [[simple background]], which is often used for character designs.

When tagging, make sure to view the original image, as images with [[transparent background]]s are previewed with a white background.
shimamura uzuki:
A character from [[Idolmaster Cinderella Girls]]. A normal girl who works enthusiastically toward becoming an idol.

She is in the unit [[New Generations (idolmaster)|]] with [[Shibuya Rin]] and [[Honda Mio]], and unit [[Pink Check School (idolmaster)|]] with [[Kohinata Miho]] and [[Igarashi Kyoko]].

Voiced by [[Oohashi Ayaka]].
cupping hands: Pressing one's hands together to form a "cup". Commonly used to hold liquids, or something small.
air bubble: A ball of air sorrounded by liquid or by a soft or frozen material. Usually goes along with [[underwater]].
pillow: A pillow is used to [[sleeping|sleep]] on and support the head/[[neck]] or other parts of the body while sleeping, [[lying]] down or [[sitting]].
pump action: A repeating [[gun|firearm]] action that is operated manually by moving a sliding handguard on the gun's forestock. When shooting, the sliding forend is pulled rearward to eject any expended cartridge and typically to cock the hammer/striker, and then pushed forward to load (chamber) a new [[ammunition|cartridge]] into the chamber. Most pump-action firearms use an integral tubular [[magazine (weapon|magazine]], although some do use detachable box magazines. Pump-action is typically associated with [[shotgun]]s.
bondage:
Bondage refers to the [i]purposeful[/i] physical restraint of a person, as with [[rope|ropes]], cords, or [[cuffs]], for [i]sexual[/i] purposes.

If the use of physical restraints is [i]non-sexual or comedic[/i], the tag [[tied up (nonsexual)|]] should be used instead of [[bondage]].

For [i]accidental[/i] restraint, see [[entangled]].

Bondage does not need to cause the target to be  [[restrained]].

Please see the “Bondage-specific” section of [[Tag Group:Sexual Positions]] for a list of bondage positions.
sneakers: [[Shoes]] designed for use in sporting activity, though commonly used as general purpose footwear. Known as [i]trainers[/i] in British English, though the more old school style of sneakers would be known as [i]plimsolls[/i] or [i]pumps[/i]. Known as [i]runners[/i] in Australia and Ireland.
miniskirt: A [[skirt]] with a hemline well above the knees. Above the middle of the thighs at least, a few centimeters below the crotch line at most. For even shorter skirts, use [[microskirt]].
tongue out:
When the [[tongue]] is past the entrance of its mouth. Primarily denotes the tongue lolling out, often unintentionally. Various facial expressions also involve jutting it out.

Note: This tag is [b]not[/b] about [[cunnilingus|tonguing out someone]].
aircraft:
Any sort of flying machine, realistic or fictional.

This also includes fictional planes which can transform into [[mecha]], and various [[airship|airships]] in the [[fantasy]], [[steampunk]], and [[science fiction]] genres.
prayer beads:
Prayer beads or Rosaries are used by members of various religions such as Roman Catholicism ([[rosary]]), Orthodox Christianity ("prayer rope, κομποσκοίνι, [i]komboskini[/i], Чётки, [i]chotki[/i]":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prayer_rope) Islam ("مسبحة [i]misbaha[/i]":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misbaha), Hinduism" माला, [i]japa mala[/i]),":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindu_prayer_beads Buddhism ("数珠, [i]shu-zhu[/i], [i]juzu[/i], 念珠, [i]nenju[/i], 佛珠, [i]fo-zhu[/i]":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist_prayer_beads ), Sikhism, and Bahá'í Faith to count the repetitions of prayers, chants or devotions. They may also be used for meditation, protection from negative energy, or for relaxation.

If the prayer beads are specifically Christian, tag [[rosary]].
greyscale:
A completely colorless, black-and-white image. The image is composed exclusively of shades of black, white, and grey. It is very common for [[comic]]s and [[doujinshi]] to be in greyscale.

The image may have small highlights of color (known as [[spot color]]s), but the image as a whole should be predominately greyscale.

Don't use color tags like [[black eyes]] or [[black hair]] when tagging greyscale images. The exception is color background tags, so tagging [[white background]], [[grey background]], or [[black background]] is fine.
yuri:
Any romantic or sexual interaction between female characters, mutual or not. If it's mutual, consider adding the [[couple]] tag.

For Danbooru purposes, [[futanari]] is not yuri. Use [[futa with female]] or [[futa with futa]] instead.

For Danbooru purposes, [[bisexual female]] activity is also not yuri. Use [[bisexual female]] instead.
light purple hair:
A character or person depicted has [b]light or grayish purple colored hair[/b].

Due to the subjective nature of color judgment and other factors (such as the lighting on the characters) there is an overlap between this tag and several other hair colors in the very light color range.  This especially true in regards to the [[pink hair]] and [[purple hair]] tags.
solo:
An image containing a single person. No one else should be visible in the image.

That means only one copy of the character. These situations [b]should not be tagged solo[/b]:

* Single characters being depicted from [[multiple views]] (post #12904)
* [[dakimakura (medium)|]] which contain [[multiple views]]
* [[dual persona]]
* [[time paradox]]

These situations should be tagged [[solo focus]], [b]not solo[/b]:

* Pictures focusing on one character among a crowd of nondescript, less detailed [[people]].
* Single characters engaged in [[tag group:sex acts|sex acts]] with [[faceless]] or [[out of frame]] characters.

Situations that can be solo include:

* A single character with one or more inanimate [[doll]]s or [[photo_(object)|]]s of other characters.
* A single character with [b]unnamed[/b] pet or object characters. Images involving animals or creatures with a character tag (talking or otherwise) alongside another character should not be tagged solo.
flat color: When an image is colored in solid blocks of color, without shadows, highlights, or gradients. The image is "flat" in that there are little to no indications of depth.
white skin:
Skin whose predominant color is 100% [[white]], like [[milk]] or [[snow]], having no pigment at all. The opposite of [[black skin]].

When the skin is a very bright shade of pink, use [[pale skin]] instead.
holographic monitor: A type of [[monitor]] that is also [[hologram]] as opposed to being made of solid matter.
medium breasts:
[[Breasts]] that are larger than [[small breasts]] and smaller than [[large breasts]].
Each breast is larger than a palmful, but smaller than the character's face.
lying:
Lying down flat on a surface, mainly being supported by the back, side or the stomach.

(Grammatical Note: Lying is the correct term to describe someone's posture. "Laying" should only be used when something is performing the action of laying something else down.)
skirt:
A skirt is a tube- or cone-shaped garment which hangs from the waist and covers all or part of the legs.

A [[dress]] should not be tagged with [[skirt]]. A dress is a one-piece outfit, while a skirt is a separate piece of clothing.
knife:
A tool or [[weapon]] consisting of a short blade and a handle, used for cutting, stabbing, or slashing.

A knife can be a [[weapon]], such as a [[dagger]] or [[combat knife]], a utensil, such as a [[kitchen knife]] or [[butter knife]], or a tool, such as a pocket knife or a [[Swiss army knife]].
dark areolae:
[[Areolae]] which are notably dark in color, usually in shades of brown to black. Regarded in Japan as an accompanying sign of [[pregnant|pregnancy]] or aging, while the more western pink-to-red spectrum is seen as a sign of youth.

Also applicable to any [[dark skin|exotic skintone]] where the areolae are actually darker than the surrounding skin.

As with [[nipples]]/[[areolae]], use this tag for images where only the the areolae is visible. For images where the nipple is fully visible, us
2girls:
An image depicting two female characters. 

Dolls only count if they act on their own. Depictions of characters on paintings etc don't count unless it plays a major role in the work. If the presence of a character is only implicated it doesn't count.
testicles:
The primary male sexual organs. They are responsible for the production of sperm, which are transported via [[cum|semen]] to the [[uterus]] of a female, at which point they are used to [[pregnant|impregnate]] her. The testicles are also a major male erogenous zone.

Technically, when testicles are tagged, it is actually the scrotum surrounding the testicles which is visible in most cases. A true view of the testicles would require a cross-section.
midair:
When a character is seen fully on the air, not touching the ground or any support.

The character should be in a setting which clearly shows that they're floating in the air compare to their surroundings, if not, simply use [[floating]], [[flying]] or [[jumping]] as applicable. Don't using this tag on background-less or otherwise ambiguous settings.

h1. See also
* [[floating]]
* [[flying]]
* [[jumping]]
* [[levitation]]
* [[falling]]
white apron: An [[apron]] that is white. Common in [[maid]] outfits.
fake screenshot: When the picture is drawn to look like a screenshot from a [[video game]], [[user interface]], a software menu, a TV series and so on.
hoodie: A sweatshirt with an attached [[hood]] that is pulled over the head. Often features a [[drawstring]]. If it has a zipper, it's a [[hooded jacket]].
grey eyes:
A character with grey-colored eyes.

Due to the subjective nature of color judgment and other factors (such as the lighting on the characters), there may be an overlap between this tag and the [[black eyes]] or [[white eyes]] tag.
feet:
When one or both of a character's feet are prominently displayed or detailed. Add [[foot focus]] when the feet are the main subject or focus of the image.

This does [b]not[/b] include feet fully covered by [[shoes]]. Feet covered by [[sandals]], [[socks]], [[thighhighs]], or [[pantyhose]] still count.
sunset:
The [[sun]] setting beneath the [[horizon]] in the [[evening]]. If the sun is no longer visible, tag it [[dusk]] instead.

Distinguishing between [[sunrise]] and [[sunset]] can be difficult, so only tag [[sunset]] if the sky hues appear more orange or red, as is most prevalent in media.

* !asset #24340888: Sunset occurs before dusk
staff:
A long stick usually for casting magic or fighting.

Do not confuse with [[wand]], [[cane]], [[scepter]], or [[musical staff]].
long hair:
Hair longer than the shoulders, up to reaching the waist. Shoulder length hair should be tagged with [[medium hair]] instead. 

Some characters may have [[very long hair]], which extends past the waist, or [[absurdly long hair]], which is longer than they are tall.
unzan:
A character in Stage 3 of [[Touhou]]'s [i][[Undefined Fantastic Object]][/i]. 

A nyuudou resembling a massive pink [[cloud]] with the face of a [[bald]], [[angry]] old man, he makes up the "Guarding and Guarded Giant Wheel" combination with the mid-boss and boss of Stage 3, [[Kumoi Ichirin]].

An imposing figure, he is actually very shy, and depends on Ichirin to speak for him. [[ZUN (artist)|]] has joked that she actually serves as his hitbox because he overshadows her so much.

Notable for being the first male character to appear in the Windows Touhou games.
kneehighs:
[[Socks]] that are knee-height, or just below knee-height.

Despite the name, kneehighs are usually slightly shorter than knee-height, usually ending a few inches below the knee, or at around 3/4 calf height.

If they're completely below shin-height, they're [[ankle socks]].

See [[over-kneehighs]] for thighhighs that reach just above the knee. See [[knee boots]] for knee-length boots.
looking back:
Indicates a subject of the image is looking behind their normal plane of vision.  This could mean they are turning their body, head, or only their eyes to look behind themselves. The subject's gaze should be directed fully or almost fully backwards over the shoulder, anywhere from 135 to 180 degrees behind them relative to their front.

Oftentimes combined with [[from behind]] and [[looking at viewer]], and also [[sideways glance]] if the character's body is partly facing away.

If the character has both of their eyes closed, use [[facing back]] instead.
lily pad:
A round leaf of the [i]Nymphaeaceae[/i] family ([[water lily flower|water lilies]]).

Lily pads float on the surface of the water and have a notch in each leaf, which helps distinguish them from [[lotus leaf|lotus leaves]], which rise above the surface of the water as they mature and do not have notches unless damaged.
horse ears: The elongated and tall ears of a [[horse]]. Made for either characters who naturally have them or [[fake animal ears|wear them as an accessory]].
power lines:
[[Cable]]s hung from [[utility pole]]s or [[transmission tower]]s to carry [[electricity]] across long distances.

Not to be confused with [[overhead line]]s, which are used by [[train]]s, or with [[speed lines]] or [[emphasis lines]], which are drawing techniques.
evening: The end of the day when the [[sunset|sun sets]].
multiple penises:
For characters surrounded by penises, see [[surrounded by penises]].

For a single character with more than one penis, see [[extra penises]].
scar on hand: A [[scar]] located somewhere on a character's hands.
earrings:
An ornament or type of [[jewelry]] worn on the earlobes or in another [[ear piercing]].

If you're sure the character is wearing only one earring, you should additionally tag the image with [[single earring]].

Do not tag earrings worn on the earlobes as [[ear piercing]]s. [[Ear piercing]] is for piercings not on the earlobe.
spread ass: Spreading the buttocks apart in order to fully expose the [[anus]].
>_<: Eyes tightly [[closed eyes|closed]] in a literal >_< shape. This usually indicates extreme [[happy|happiness]], but it can also be used to indicate pain, [[embarrassed|embarrassment]], or [[sad]]ness.
gagged:
When someone in the image has their mouth restrained to prevent speech or mouth movement, either with a [[gag|purpose-built gag]], such as a [[ball gag]], or by an improvised gag, such as [[tape]] over the mouth. Images commonly involved [[bondage]].
